linkTarget.anchoringText: The Southern part of Rajasthan block located in the North-West part of India in Barmer basin consists of many geographically dispersed marginal fields with varying crude and reservoir properties. Figure-1 shows field location map for satellite fields (Saraswati, Raageshwari, Guda, NE and NI).

The anchors are designed to land the pump, prevent the movement and to provide the sealing between the high pressured discharge section and low-pressure intake section of the pump. The main components include the adapter head, threaded insert steel-rubber seal, split cone, slip assembly and body mandrel with J-slot grooves. Refer to Figure-2 for detailed equipment listing.

In case the surface unit is modified, the same universal foundation is used for erecting the new unit. By adopting universal portable foundation, the company saves on production time and cost by re-using and readjusting the same foundation. Figure-3 shows casted concrete base at the production plant, ready to be transported to the well site.

The well was completed for natural flow with 7" production casing, 2-7/8" tubing and 7" retrievable packer. Refer to Figure-5 for self-flowing completion schematic. Refer to Figure-4 for production trend of GUDA-A on self-flow. Under appraisal stage, the well initially was put for extended well test on self-flow. After 4 months of production, well seized to flow on 29th Jan-2015.

The well was completed for natural flow with 7" production casing, 2-7/8" tubing and 7" retrievable packer. Refer to Figure-5 for self-flowing completion schematic. Refer to Figure-4 for production trend of GUDA-A on self-flow. Under appraisal stage, the well initially was put for extended well test on self-flow. After 4 months of production, well seized to flow on 29th Jan-2015.

The cost estimate included deferred oil production due to the work-over operation; rig spread the cost and tangible cost. After pump installation well was put on production and was closely monitored to observe any issue with the pump performance on insert anchor. The pump successfully completed 1 year of run-life. Post success of this job, Insertable anchor was used in the entire fields install down-hole pump in wells with profile-less string. Refer to Figure-6 for completion schematic of the well on SRP.
Figure-7 shows the trend for GUDA-A on SRP and on Self-flow and series of event during the life of the well.

MBH-A is horizontal fracced well in the barmer-hill formation. Well was initially on self-flow and then was put on jet-pump. But with jet-pump, the operator was not able to give the required draw-down. It was decided to produce the well on sucker rod pump. The pilot for installation of hydraulic rod pump unit was conducted for this well. The well has packer completion with 7" casing and 3-1/2" tubing. SSD has been installed in the well for jet-pumping. Please refer to Figure-8 for details on completions.

Please refer to Figure-9 for the detailed equipment listing. The mast assembly and hydraulic cylinder are mounted directly on the well head. The polished rod is clamped to the cylinder rod that runs through the hydraulic cylinder. Proximity switches are installed on the mast assembly controlling the rod movement direction and change of stroke. Hoses are connected from the hydraulic cylinder to the accumulator via servo valve.

Looking at the production requirement, expected loads it was decided to install 150-40000 unit i.e. 150" maximum stroke length and 40000 lbs as the maximum load carrying capacity. 30-250-RWBC-20-3-0-0 down-hole pump was installed with 1" rods (molded guides installed). Please refer to Figure-10 for further details on other model types.

Well was on HRP for over 90 days and all the pump and production parameters were closely monitored. All the parameters were healthy and production was constant throughout with average oil production approximately 180-190 BOPD (100 BOPD o jet pump) Refer to Figure-12 for completion schematic on SRP. Figure-11 shows the pump parameters i.e. operating SPM, peak polished rod load (PPRL) and minimum polished rod load (MPRL) during the life f the system.

Well was on HRP for over 90 days and all the pump and production parameters were closely monitored. All the parameters were healthy and production was constant throughout with average oil production approximately 180-190 BOPD (100 BOPD o jet pump) Refer to Figure-12 for completion schematic on SRP. Figure-11 shows the pump parameters i.e. operating SPM, peak polished rod load (PPRL) and minimum polished rod load (MPRL) during the life f the system.

The polished rod runs through a channel inside the rack and is suspended from the top by a conventional rod clamp. An induction motor, coupled to the rack-and pinion mechanism through a gear box, cycles the rack up and down to reciprocate the rod. The rack is lubricated with each stroke by submersion into a fully contained oil bath. Refer to figure-13 for detailed equipment listing.

30-175-RHAC-18-4-0-0 down-hole pump was installed with 1" and 7/8" sucker rod. The LRP unit installed was 20-56 i.e. 56-inch maximum surface stroke length and 20,000 lbs load carrying capacity. Well was closely monitored to observe any operational or performance challenge on the unit. The well successfully completed over 365 days on LRP producing average oil rate of 250 BOPD. The unit was operating on 8 SPM. Refer to Figure-14 for detailed completion schematic on SRP.
